thread.title: Tomi Lahren Strikes Back At The Feminist Definition Of A ‘Real Woman’
thread.title_full: Tomi Lahren Strikes Back At The Feminist Definition Of A ‘Real Woman’

author: Fred Maxwell
title: Tomi Lahren Strikes Back At The Feminist Definition Of A ‘Real Woman’
text:
‘Not My President’s Day’ Protests Draw Thousands Across America 
She refuted the idea that she was a victim because she was a woman, saying, “I didn’t wake up this morning … feeling like the victimhood narrative was a part of my story.” 
She reminded her audience that, “Real women don’t have to remind the world every single day that history once slighted us.” 
“Real women don’t wake up and skip work to march for abortions and paid contraceptives, while women in less fortunate parts of the world wake up without basic human rights,” Lahren remarked.   
The New York Times described the Day Without A Woman protests as “far smaller than the masses who turned the women’s marches on Jan. 21 into a phenomenon.” The paper quoted organizers of the event as saying 30,000 women had pledged online to participate in some form, but noted it was difficult to measure actual participation because employers could not provide counts of women who stayed home and there were no figures available yet from the retail marketplace. 
Lahren commented on what she viewed as the silliness of the Day Without A Woman protest, saying, “I don’t know about a day without women, but I could use a day without this nasty feminist b.s. masqueraded as women’s rights.” 
“Yeah, some challenges might be a little greater for women,” Lahren said. “But let me tell ya, it feels a whole hell of a lot better to overcome those challenges than it does to dwell on them, complain about them or use them as an excuse to fall short.” 
Addressing young women on what it means to be a real woman, Lahren showed a short video of Madonna saying she had thought, an awful lot, about blowing up the White House after President Trump’s inauguration, along with one of Ashley Judd proclaiming herself to be “a nasty woman.”
